title: How was Italy able to defeat Ethiopia in the Second Italo-Ethiopian War but not the first? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is because there was a huge difference in the Italian effort made to take Ethiopia between the 1st and 2nd wars. The first Italian Ethiopian war was basically a small Italian army of 15,000 men whose commander made a the blunder of splitting his forces and putting them out in the open against a force of Ethiopians that outnumbered the Italians perhaps 5 to 1. The separated Italians in the open were destroyed as was the other half which went to the rescue. So there you go. In the first war the force sent in was too small and abysmally led. Now for the second Italian Ethiopian war. This one was much bigger and bloodier and this time the Italians and their native allies invaded Ethiopia with a modern army over 250,000 men strong. They had tanks and complete air supremacy. The Ethiopian armies, who did still have more men, had pretty much nothing else. They had ancient weapons, very few modern rifles, no tanks, and no air force. They could not hope to stop the Italians the way they did in 1896. Their armies were destroyed one after another on the ground and constantly harassed from the air as the Italian army pressed further and further into Ethiopia finally taking its capital and causing its emperor to flee. In about 6 months and costing relatively light Italian casualties they had taken Ethiopia. The differences in the first war and second are obvious. The first one with merely 15,000 men and not much else. Poorly led, engulfed, and annihilated. The second war saw Mussolini's military in action and he was taking no chances on anything but victory. 250,000 troops, numerous tanks, the Italian air force controlled the skies (and dropped gas on the fleeing tribesmen just to increase their casualties. They were adequately led as well. This gave Ethiopia, the last free African nation at that time, no chance for victory against the technologically superior Italians who were employing all the weapons of modern warfare against the brave but barefooted Ethiopian tribesmen who had spears and at best had rifles from the turn of the century. So the difference was simply a far larger and better equipped army. Modern weapons like tanks, artillery, and airplanes. The Ethiopians were slaughtered with figures of up to 275,000 military men dead and 500,000 civilians. That's in comparison to about 10,000 Italian soldiers lost.
